item.title: CHP-Equipped District Energy: A Winning Strategy for LEED and PEER (Webinar) – January 18, 2017
item.description:
This webinar highlights the potential significant LEED point impact for buildings that connect to CHP-equipped district energy systems, describes how buildings connected to district energy systems earn points in the LEED for Building Design and Construction: New Construction and Major Renovations rating system, provides an overview of USGBC’s PEER rating system and how the energy-efficiency benefits of CHP-equipped district energy systems are recognized, and explains opportunities to get involved with the development of LEED and PEER as they relate to district energy and CHP.

  • CHP-Equipped District Energy: A Winning Strategy for LEED® and PEER (PDF)(29 pp, 1 MB)
item.dc:creator: bo_zaks

item.title: Treatment of District Energy CHP Outputs in LEED® for Building Design and Construction: New Construction and Major Renovations
item.description:
This fact sheet summarizes how buildings connected to a CHP- equipped district energy system can earn more LEED® points than they could otherwise earn. It presents guidance for meeting the LEED® Minimum Energy Performance prerequisite and calculating points under the Optimize Energy Performance credit, and a hypothetical example demonstrating the application of the USGBC methodology for determining OEP points.

  • Treatment of District Energy CHP Outputs in LEED® for Building Design and Construction: New Construction and Major Renovations (PDF)(11 pp, 281 K)

item.title: Why CHP is a Good Fit for Commercial Buildings and Workplaces, NFMT High Performance Buildings (Presentation) – May 4, 2016
item.description:
On May 4, the EPA Combined Heat and Power Partnership (CHPP) held a panel at the 2016 NFMT High Performance Buildings Conference. The topic of the panel was “Why CHP is a Good Fit for Commercial Buildings and Workplaces.” Presentations provided an introduction to CHP, an overview of packaged CHP systems, summary of modern absorption chillers, and an overview of how CHP can help earn LEED® points.

  • Why CHP is a Good Fit for Commercial Buildings and Workplaces (PDF)(50 pp, 11 MB)

Guidelines for Case Studies

EPA CHP Partners are invited to submit case studies to be displayed in their Partner Profiles. Each case studies will highlight a successful CHP project in which the Partner was involved.

Guidelines for case studies:

  • Each case study must be submitted as URLs. The CHP Partnership cannot accept electronic case study files.
  • Titles must be provided for each case study submitted.
  • Case study content must not imply any endorsement from EPA or the EPA CHP Partnership.
  • There are no length requirements, but we recommend that case studies be five pages or less.
  • Up to three case studies can be submitted.

Please submit case studies to chp@epa.gov or through the “Update My Info” page.
